This game and the developers are the most BS ive ever seen.

You play solo and get a group of 3 or 4 Premades. They troll you, they take turns attacking / killing you and if you fight back or leave you get a ban. So you are forced to sit it out, waste your time, just to -at the end of game- get kicked. And then you get a ban for being kicked. 

That way, one or another, you keep stacking your cooldown times. Then you come back after it ran out, just to not load into a game. Which isnt your fault. You have played countless other games, GTA, LOL, Battlefield, Phasmophobia, Rocket League, you name it. All working perfectly fine. But CSGO? No it doesnt. You get stuck in a loading Screen unable to join the match you accepted. You restart the game, if you are lucky without the standard "this game is already running"-fault message. You try to load into the game again. Maybe again. No matter how many tries, once you load into this crap, you see that you are stuck in warm-up alone with a bot. Everyone else left and so do you. Just to see? You get a cooldown for not connecting to the match. 

And in the few rare ocasions that you actually make it into a game without anything mentioned above you either have cheaters, russians refusing to speak english, a 8 year old kid screaming his lungs out or an e-girl (that the rest of your team jumps on trying to hit on her or keeps "having fun" taking part in sexual harrassment. 

And if all that is not happening to you, you might enjoy spending quality time with your gambling addiction opening boxes for ~3 EUR and if you are lucky you get a skin worth  ~2 EUR every billion boxes opened. 

Seriously, its not a bad game itself. But community and developers? Just for them Im praying for another '39 or that they have tourists in their office like CH Magazine had in Paris.

Okay, if you really reading reviews about CS:GO it means that you are just looking for funny comments or YOU WANT THIS GAME TO BE YOUR ROUTINE, YOUR WORK. In that case I give you one advice: aim is the second important thing in that game. First is your understanding of everything that happens. What your enemy will do, how you can surprise them, what move will be the best in specific situations, etc. But it doesn't means that aim is nothing. It means a lot, but with understanding of the game it will be much easier to use your aim skills at full power. Good luck bro.

To all players with or without prime, 1st, 2nd, 3rd class citizens. In writing this statement of intent, I would like to represent the non-prime players who have been pushed to the margins of society in the past time.
Given that we were all born and raised on the same planet, we are all the same. Do you remember the good old days when Prime was not a thing? Stack-5 days without leaving your non-prime bro behind? Do you remember the times when you screamed in the cyber cafÃ©s after a 1v5 clutch? Or those days nade stacking against cheaters with the bros?
Alas, Valve is like a demon, for his sake he divided us. The teammates were suddenly divided high-class and low-class citizens, not because of their ranks but because of Prime. There were parents who have lost their children, women who have lost their husbands, and friends who are no longer pals, all because of Prime. There were people who even wanted to k!ll themselves when there was only 1 match away from lvl 21, right in front of heaven's gate. There were youngsters who were trying hard, suddenly lost in life. There were also young merchants who suddenly lost their daily bread. Some could not bear the pressure and had to leave, forever.
I decided today I wanted to take the power back. I had a revelation that I had to be empowered to be a non-primer today more than ever. Non-primers are also human beings. Non-primers have the right to be loved, to be treated with dignity and respect. On behalf of the non-prime community, please grant that right to us!

Chess is dead

Chess hasn't been updated in almost 200 years and it's obvious the devs have abandoned it. The greedy creators took your money and laughed all the way to the bank.

I remember back in 705 AD when chess was fun. Then they started adding stupid features no one wanted like "Castling" and "En Passant" instead of listening to player feedback and fixing game-breaking bugs. I've been complaining for YEARS about the collision-detection glitch with the horsey. The "clipping-thru-pieces" bug has been abused to death and the lazy devs refuse to fix it.

Don't support this awful behaviour and boycott this company.

I'm not one to leave a review for many games, but Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is one of the most surreal "experiences" of my entire career. I have met a wide range of people, from actual NPC's whom I cannot control by pressing e while spectating, to Canadians playing on the same NA servers cursing me out in French while getting spitroasted in mid. I have developed a gambling addiction which is not even fueled by my wallet, but my friends who has gotten a second-hand addiction through watching. I have to continue fueling the addiction every week or else the e-devil will burst out through my floorboards and force me to actually play the game with the people you find while solo queuing instead of just gambling for 60% of the hours you spend on this fucking application.  
You always think that the crate isn't worth opening until you realize that you only have to spend $5 to open, and you think about hitting big profit on the market and how worth it will be. Then since you spent $5 you might as well open 2 crates to double your odds right? Wrong. The odds of pulling a profitable skin out of crates is less than you discovering actual Spanish gold and being set for life without touching the steam marketplace. It is 99.25% of you pulling a skin that costs from .03 cents to around $2.30, which isn't even enough to pay off the key price. 
I hope whoever plays this game doesn't develop a crippling gambling addiction and focuses more of their hours off the marketplace and on the recoil patterns. :)

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Great tactical/movement fps that holds up today despite it's age. My only issues are the technicality of it being free to play, while it is free, and I got tons of enjoyment without spending money, it still locks you out of the wingman gamemode unless you play against bots. My other issue is that even though the CSGO movement engine is the smoothest, and most technical engine I have ever seen, it feels that this game dosent showcase well in the official maps and I hope the next map valve adds utilizes more underused features like drowning, airstrafing, maybe surfing. Overall this game is a 10/10 for any fps fan, it has a little for everyone

Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Possibly the most addictive, frustrating and satisfying game I've ever played. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better. Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If youâ€™re a Call of Duty player, youâ€™re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what itâ€™s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Counter Strike and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The question asked by Steam, prompting me to write a review is exactly as it follows "Would you recommend this game to other players?". To answer truthfully and bluntly? No.

The reason? Let's take a look at the current monetization model of the game itself: The game is free to play. You can download it, play casual matches, competitive matches, you basically have full access to the game itself. But here's the catch - you can't earn "crate drops" or "skin drops". That's a shame, surely, but no major inconvenience. No, what truly is a bad draw here is that you're essentially barred from filtered matchmaking, That means more cheaters for you, and you can't earn rankings. For anyone who is North American, you would have to pay around $14.99 to get prime access. The same amount the game costed before going free to play. For anyone who isn't North American...mileage may vary. A lot. For example, in Brasil, the game used to cost around R$32. Affordable, not outrageous. Then it became Free To Play with the Prime Clause. Prime was around R$25.00. Very much affordable. Then the Prime Clause was taken down, and the price for priem access bumped to to R$85.00. What? No idea. Regional Pricing apparently died in Gabe Newell's closet when it comes to this game.

Alright, beyond sketchy pricing and senseless monetization models, let's take a look at the game itself. Rampant hackers in and out of Prime filtered matchmaking. VAC is faulty at best, completely unhinged at worse (Blocking up matchmaking for random players until they've restarted their computers or steam, removing you from matches by 'mistake', etc.). Extreme toxicity, very flimsy Anti-Game behavior punishment system, exploitable networking settings, lacking map design, negligence of game bugs & issues, extreme crate marketing with little to no substantial updates to much needed sectors of the game.

If you can ignore all of that, or if it simply does not affect you, then by all means it's a solid FPS competitive game. Grab five or so friends, hop in a few matches. The core gameplay mechanics are easy to learn but hard to master. It's also one of the few alive FPS games in a competitive enviroment that hasn't surrendered to the flashy appeal of superpowers. I don't know about you, but I'll take a good ol' flashbang grenade any time over a fireball cast over a battlefield littered by ice walls, shadow monsters and colorful little magic tricks.

Charles White Jr.[4] (born August 2, 1994), better known as Cr1TiKaL (pronounced "critical"), is an American YouTuber and Twitch streamer. Best known for his commentary videos on YouTubeâ€”as well as his live streams on Twitch, where he most often streams gaming contentâ€”his content is distinguishable for his monotone voice and deadpan delivery of comedic commentary.[5] In addition, White is a co-founder and co-owner of esports organization Moist Esports and co-founder and member of musical duo The Gentle Men.

As of August 2022, White's YouTube channel has gained over 5.6 billion video views and over 11.2 million subscribers, averaging 151.4 million views per month on the platform;[6] his Twitch channel has gained over 4.3 million followers and over 59.3 million views.[7][8]

I would be amazed if anyone is still looking at reviews for this game after all this time but:

This game is my own personal hell and I can't escape it.

The servers will upset you, your teammates will upset you, and hackers will upset you.

The moments in between are a fun adrenaline rush that mimic some kind of cocaine fueled bender - you'll feel invincible and horrible all at the same time.

With that being said, I've made lifelong friends playing this game and can never stay away from it for more than 3 years at a time. This game is like that abusive, gas-lighting ex that your friends warned you about.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Counter Strike Global Offensive and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 50 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Counter Strike and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

CSGO is a very good game that you can play when your happy, sad, bored, tired, or most other emotions because there are so many fun options including just playing with some well designed bots that you can very easily customise to your skill set. One thing that I don't like is that most of the modes are search and destroy, and I know that that is how these games work but I would personally like more variety. My favourite mode is probably the Arms Race because I enjoy being able to try all of the guns to find out how they work and even extend my skill set and work out of my comfort zone.

I probably won't have a popular opinion here but it is how I feel none the less.

I played CS a lot when it was first released as a mod for Half-life. I put hundreds of hours into both pub matches and matches with my friends in private servers. I stopped playing it at about the time that it was about to make the move to a retail product

Counter-strike as a franchise is something of a time capsule. It is a example of a late 90's shooter frozen in time that never really changes and that is probably what makes it both novel for the average gamer and important for the competitive scene that has formed around it (and taken control of it in a lot of ways).

Because a e-sports style competitive scene has formed around Counter-strike, it puts Valve in a difficult position because they can't really change anything without facing harsh resistance from the veteran players. Even minor visual changes are met with extreme criticism because they may upset the carefully cultivated meta.

It was not always like this. When I was playing, the idea of e-sports level competitive play was only just starting to manifest and thus it was more rare to find the ultra-competitive players who get wrapped up in memorizing spread patterns, researching dominant strategies and reading up on the established meta. A lot of players back then were just there because it was fun to play and had a huge playerbase (thus meaning that servers were always reasonably available).

Playing Counter-strike back then was not the commitment that it can be now. The overall behavior of the playerbase was different. You may have gotten the usual smack talk during a match but you did not have people telling you to do things exactly this certain way in order for the whole thing to play out like a E-sports match either (at least not in any great number).

Playing Counter-strike now is essentially a test to see how much you like getting pub-stomped by uber-experienced and ultra-competitive players. It is not a overly welcoming place for new players (though not everyone is negative to new players and some will help you out) and has a culture all of it's own. This culture will either be really cool to you or annoying as hell, there is not much room for anything in between.

If you want a competitive gaming experience that is largely shaped by the most competitive (and vocal) players. Counter-strike is for you. If you want something more like a typical modern shooter or something that is more casual, It's not the best place to start.

In the end, this is just a opinion, I understand that Counter-strike is going to be a different experience for different people. I know that I am probably a bit old and thus missed the competitive level gaming boat by a few years but that does not change the fact that I have played (and own) Counter-strike: Global offensive and the culture that has formed around that game is not something I can really get into. Your mileage (of course) may very.

In CS:GO, you play the role of a hot masculine special agent, whitch objective it is to either defuse a bomb planted by the terrorists or plant the bomb as a said terrorist. In this game, you encounter a healthy amount of cultural and political diversity, from countries such as russia, poland, middle east and russia and middle east and poland etc. These people, especially from russia, are very open-minded and accepting of whoever you are. From my experience, they really like the LGBTQ+ community and people from Germany. It is a great game to meet new friends from many different countries like russia, russia, russia and russia. You can also improve your language skills just by listening to the lovely sweet conversations by your mates in the CS:GO voice chat.
So anyway, wo also gets a stiffy when dominated by a russian cheater with a masculine, bone deep voice or is it just me? I mean just the thought of me getting absolutely obliterated by a muscular north-eastern Siberian young man who fights with bears on a regular basis. The thought of you being stuck in one lobby with him with no way out because your mates won't surrender. The warm and sweaty feeing of helplessness does really drive me INSANE ( in a good way///) I usually inseminate the underside of my desk after the eight round because i am a weak ass but i really wish i could go for longer. Because of my kink, i wake up every morning flaming with ecxitement to hop on a fresh round of de_office and try my luck. But because of my relatively high trust factor and the recent effectiveness of VAC (curse this damned programm) i can no longer have fun 8x a day :(. It is really hard to encounter cheaters nowadays which really disappoints me. Sometimes i really think about quitting the game because there are too few cheaters. I really wish valve would do something to combat the frequent banning of cheaters. In my opinion, they should remove VAC and the overwatch system, because they are too effective and ruin my fun.
I think i might have lost my way, but i shall continue. Just hearing the ï·½ ï·½ from your lovely arab teammate makes you feel like you're in another country. I recommend playing CS:GO with an open voice chat, especially if you have mental health problems and/or suicidal thoughts, because your teammates and even your enemies will be very supportive and help you seek appropriate help for your problems. The CS:GO community is a wonder of its own and worth exploring. Playing CS:GO is like balm for the soul. It helps you find inner peace and guides you on your path to your better self.
CS:GO is the cool breeze from the west, the crackling of the autumn-colored leaves under your boots, the sparkling of cool water in the summer heat, the reflections of light on a sweaty, muscular male body, the Creme Ã  la Creme of video games by far.

This game is great if you are a fan of fps games. The downside is that it is much harder to learn compared to other fps titles, but also has much higher skill ceiling.
You MUST buy prime status upgrade with this game otherwise you will get matched in cheater lobbies in matchmaking.

Positives:

- more tactical sided than other popular shooting games
- team-based game
- shooting mechanics feel great when you learn them
- made a lot of friends thru matchmaking

Negatives:

- running on very outdated game engine
- has many unfixed bugs
- matchmaking is not reliable
- random russian teammates
- cheaters

Great game overall, just needs game engine update of some sort.

CS:GO is a good game, i have played every version made to date, 1.5, 1.6, and so on to cs:go, i like the game very much i enjoy meeting new people on casual servers and deathmatch, adding them and playing MM with them, the community as a whole is quite friendly and most people get along well, as with any game there a sometimes trolls and people that just want to ruin other peoples day, just ignore them and find the good people talk with a positive attitude and you will notice people will start to enjoy playing with you, the MatchMaking is overall alright they are always trying to adjust it and make it better for what it is, the only issue i have so far with this game is the trust factor, have one or 2 good games in a row or verse a group of trolls, it can ruin your gaming experience very quickly, and it shouldnt be the case at all, play 2 games ina row with 30 kills around this mark and your almost certainly going to get reported by people that either rage every time they get killed or having a bad day etc, and its not fair that your gaming experience can be destroyed by the trolls that are doing it to you, valve is just rewarding them and punishing you on a system that in almost all cases seems flawed, other then that be a positive member of the community and you should have ALOT of fun playing this game

My main source of memories from Counter-Strike: Source come from just finding a random server, getting in and being horrible at the game. I loved every second of it. I want to preface what I'm about to say with the fact that I don't hate eSports. It's cool to see gaming skills finally get recognized as having *some* sort of importance. But this game, even a casual match, feels so competitive it hurts. It doesn't even feel like it's funny anymore. It's just stressful. 

Before this game went to F2P and was more casual friendly, this would have easily been a positive review. Alas, times have changed.

If you're into competitive gaming and eSports, power to you, have fun with this. But for everyone else, just go with Source. Or maybe I just need to play more of it. I dunno.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive

A great competitive game that also has its pitfalls. One of them is the trust factor known to many... Unfortunately, it is a matter that can change the mind of new players and they will play against cheaters.
Conclusion (I evaluate the style of the game and its purpose):
Graphics : 9/10 (this is a competitive game so graphics are not that important)
Teammates : 5/10
Game system : 5/10 (Waiting forever for source 2)
Gameplay: 10/10
Anticheat : 2/10 (even with a good trust factor you can play against cheaters who don't get banned for maybe a year...)

Overall rating: 62%

I am a 48 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Counter Strike and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I have been playing Counter Strike since the games inception as a Mod for Half Life.
Each version has offered updated features and maps with a huge community of map makers.
That said my opinion is that it's an aging game engine long overdue for an overhaul compared 
to the IW and UNREAL engines which offer features like aiming down sights, auto healing, throwing back
grenades, vehicles etc. Imagine a whole new Counter Strike based on either engine with expanded graphics, effects and game play similar to Insurgency??
That said I enjoy playing Counter Strike and playing maps created by the community.
I loved Counter Strike Source with weapons skins and ease of browsing and playing custom maps but since Counter Strike started using the DOT NET platform it did away with modding in favor of subscription to maps thru Steam which all in all is not bad.
VERY GOOD MECHS AND CHALLENGING AT MOST POINTS BUT OVERALL ENJOYABLE GAME

Would be a greater game if the noobware-users actually had a chance of getting VAC-Banned for cheating. Not like now, or for like the past 5 years(if not more) with a outdated non-function anti-cheat(VAC). And also, could you pls stop queing low lvl's steam acc's, with little to no hours, up against high lvl's steam acc's with many hours? cause that almost certainly a guaranteed cheat match(european servers atleast). Let the low lvl's play against each other, then they'll have a blast while cheating their socks of against other cheaters, and its even more fair(same advantages: esp, aimhack etc.).

- I mean come on? where are the ban-waves at? like in the past? haven't seen that i a long time,
 or even a blatant cheater getting a VAC-ban, which i've been que'd up against previously(they still cheating strong for years). Even small time game-developers with 5% of the personal as that of VALVE, do it much better without using a to invasive anti-cheat meassure. 

I would consider supporting the game again buying keys for cases and etc. when i see some improvements that make the game enjoyable. No point in supporting cash-crabs(cases, models etc) if it only goes to more of the same, with more, and more cheaters(whats the point in having/getting skins for a unenjoyable cheat-infested game that's unplayable for others than cheaters which btw. ain't spending any money on the game). The skins gonna get devalued as time passes, and more, and more legit players leave the game. But i guess it's better with cheaters vs cheaters that ain't spending a dime. Thats kinda brilliant, because then you don't have to make more buyable pixels because none will be buying it! :D

- BTW: it would be great if you could reset my trustfactor-score? because it feels like i've been cursed with a very low trustfactor score. All my matches is usually against full cheat lobbies with low steam lvl's etc. And thats not fair, or enjoyable, because i don't cheat, and i ain't planning on cheating anytime soon. But If it's not because of a low trustfactor score, then it can only be that the european servers mostly consists of more cheaters than legit players(could be), or i'm just super unlucky where everytime i start a match iget cheaters(for the most part).

The main reason I would suggest anyone to ever install this game onto their computer is that if you have a particular disdain toward other forms of communication on the internet but still enjoy speaking with others the 'Community servers' section of this video-game offers discussion to occur though with a few caveats. I think this suggestion is only desirable short-term, and not a full substitution for your daily social interaction. The interactions that you have on this game seemingly go as 2/200 (%1) the other percentage and potential 198 individuals that you encounter are going to not be very kind, however, the two individuals from this potential grouping that you do meet are people that you will never forget. I think with this particular situation in mind it is still worth playing. I do not think I would ever consider continuing if it were not for the servers ran by the community and some of the people that I have met throughout my time playing. I am in forever debt to those that I have met, and the meaning that they have given me regardless if we are still friends or not. I will take the moment that I played a quad-ot match on train with ten random people, all of us had a good time and were making jokes, laughing and importantly all of us were passionately playing. I will never meet these people ever again. I will never forget this moment.

A ray of light shines down on a leather-bound storybook. The book opens and a voice begins reading its text:                

SHREK: Once upon a time there was a [[Storybook Princess|lovely princess]]. But she had an enchantment upon her of a fearful sort which could only be broken by love's first kiss. She was locked away in a castle guarded by a terrible [[Storybook Dragon|fire-breathing dragon]]. Many brave knights had attempted to free her from this dreadful prison, but none prevailed. She waited in the dragon's keep in the highest room of the tallest tower. For [[Storybook Prince|her true love]] and true love's first kiss.                 

The voice laughs. A big, green hand rips out a page of the book and shuts it closed.                

SHREK: Like that's ever gonna happen. What a load of -                

We see an outhouse and hear the sound of a toilet flushing. Out steps [[Shrek (character)|SHREK]], an ogre, who tugs at his underwear and shakes his foot of the page still stuck to his shoe. He looks lovingly at the [[swamp]] he calls home, and goes about his daily routine. This includes taking a mud shower, brushing his teeth with bugs, bathing in a muddy pond, gathering giant slugs for dinner, and painting a warning sign. 

In a [[Village (Duloc)|nearby village]], an [[Angry Mobs|angry mob]] gather up to go after Shrek. At night they gather their torches and pitchforks and enter the swamp, trampling over Shrek's warning signs. Shrek sees them after investigating the commotion, rolling his eyes. The villagers stop outside Shrek's home, unaware that Shrek is sneaking up behind them.

'''NIGHT - NEAR SHREK'S HOME'''                                     

Villager 1: Think it's in there?                                     

Villager 2: All right. Let's get it!                                     

Villager 1: Whoa. Hold on. Do you know what that thing can do to you?                                      

Villager 3: Yeah, it'll grind your bones for its bread.                

Shrek chuckles, revealing himself to be standing behind the mob.                                     

SHREK: Yes, well, actually, that would be a giant.                                      

The mob gasp.                                      

SHREK: Now, ogres, oh they're much worse. They'll make a suit from your freshly peeled skin...                                      

Shrek slowly approaches as the villagers back away in fear.                                      

Villagers: No!                                     

SHREK: They'll shave your liver. Squeeze the jelly from your eyes! Actually, it's quite good on toast.                                      

Villager 1: Back! Back, beast! Back! I warn ya!                 

The villager waves his torch in Shrek's face. Shrek casually licks his fingers and pinches the flame, extinguishing the torch. The villager drops it.                

Villager 1: Right...

You play this game because of either sheer nostalgia or because its drinking/strat roulette or just because you have nothing else to play. It has lost it's luster from years ago when everyone knew the pros, the clips were fresh and the tournaments meant something. The maps. sounds, and guns are all different to the point that if you played this back in say 2015 and pick it up now it's a shell or clone of it's former self. If they ever make CS:GO 2 by using the source engine, as much of the old player-base wishes, and implement skins the same way the competition (Valorant, plus they stole map devs already) uses them with no trading and no market to stop this insufferable pseudo NFT melarky and listen to the fans and dedicated players the game would be much more fun. I miss the old sounds, a simple toggle could fix this. I hate how we don't see our progress with rank. I miss the old goofy stuff  like jump scouting. Perhaps it's the old boomer in me or perhaps the game has actually gotten less fun for both the old and the new player bu the game just isn't in a good place. If the ever decide to actually make a second release (which they won't because they make too much from the damned marketplace transactions) and sucessfully implement the changes I have listed or even take into consideration what the community wants then they will have a true hit on their hands.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead- murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time - something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange - uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" - on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS:GO) is a worldwide phenomenon, and now Valve's hit team-based shooter is free-to-play! Choose your side -- terrorist or counter-terrorist -- and engage is fast-paced team-based battles with a variety of objectives. Or, take part in the Danger Zone battle royale mode where it's every man (or team) for himself!

Each side has a number of different factions it can represent, each with its own distinct look in both clothes and weapons. You can alter your loadout to suit your needs and to provide the proper role for your team. Teamwork is vital, and there's a limited amount of time to complete your objective, so you'll need to communicate your objectives with your comrades.

CS:GO also has an active esports presence, making it one of the most successful competitive games in the world. It also has a complex economy, with some weapon skins going for hundreds of dollars. Whether you play casual or competitive, for fun or for prizes, CS:GO offers plenty of action!

For me CS GO is one of the best games in history,I remember playing CS 1.6 at internet cafes back in the day and this is a huge upgrade of that,altrough a lot of people say it s not worth playing CS GO in 2022 due to the new shooters and open-world game Imma give you 5 good reasons why you still should play CS GO in 2022,feel free to disagree or agree with me,so here we go.

 Due to the persevering popularity of this legendary game, a betting market has grown, focusing on popular eSports. Other games you can wager on include DotA 2 and League of Legends, but CS:GO remains unwavering on its throne. Getting well-informed before placing your bet is crucial even in traditional sports betting, and especially when it comes to eSports. Therefore, here are the top reasons why playing CS:GO is a great idea even in 2022 (and beyond):
 Straightforward gaming 
Extremely entertaining
 Undemanding requirements 
Globally widespread community
 Available in steam, free-to-play.

Straightforward Gaming
Playing this legendary game is effortless and intuitive, which is also among the top reasons to consider it. CS:GO features a relatively flat learning curve thanks to logical controls and a learning time measured in seconds. 

Getting the hang of different available weapons requires several rounds, and mastering the maps is equally quick. You can also adjust to using the best weapon for each map, which involves a degree of personal preference. Among this gameâ€™s best features is that it also includes an FAQ page. If you ever need additional answers and no one to turn to, this resource could prove invaluable.

In other words, you should have no trouble getting into playing CS:GO if youâ€™ve played first-person shooter games before. Additionally, youâ€™ll mostly play as a part of relatively small teams of between two and six people, making managing easy. Simultaneously, despite the availability of numerous maps, players tend to repeat half a dozen over and over, helping you get your bearings more quickly.

You may need a round or two to find your way around, but thatâ€™s part of the fun. The more you play, the more youâ€™ll inadvertently practice and become better. However, CS:GO requires you to practice shooting as this aspect of the game acts as the great equalizer. The gaming action will become more intense as your shooting skills progress, which always accounts for more fun.

Extremely Entertaining
The CS franchise is famous worldwide as one of the most straightforward yet most thrilling first-person shooters in video gaming history. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a natural evolution of the first game and one thatâ€™s just as entertaining. Unlike the original title, CS:GO focuses more on multiplayer action and tournaments. Whether you are a spectator or player, you can choose between virtually countless different contests, events, and competitions around the globe.

For example, ESL One: Cologne is one of the best events to attend, with RFRSH and ESL generally organizing the highest-level competitions in the pro-circuit. These competitions bring together some of the most skilled professional players from the world over. Consequently, the level of skill spectators witness in each event is mind-boggling and, at times, too unreal to believe. When looking to improve your skills and work out new strategies, we recommend following these pro-level eSports contests.

Undemanding Requirements
When it comes to the top reasons for playing CS:GO, this game excels where other titles generally lose audiences. The industryâ€™s general rule is that the newer the game, the more advanced the hardware it requires. However, because CS:GO is almost a decade old, you wonâ€™t need a beastly machine to enjoy its benefits.

Gaming on a budget is the harsh reality for millions of enthusiasts worldwide, and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive solves this problem. The minimum hardware and software requirements you need for this game include an Intel Core 2 Duo E6600/AMD Phenom X3 8750, 2 GB Ram, 15 GB HDD, 256 MB or higher GPU, Windows 7, Vista (even XP!), and DirectX 9 compatibility. Thatâ€™s it!

Globally Widespread Community
Stalled communities are one of the most impactful downsides of countless otherwise excellent shooter titles. However, CS:GO stands proud as one of the internetâ€™s most active communities for almost a decade. You wonâ€™t need to deal with long queues or boring matches against the same people. Instead, this title focuses on every individual playerâ€™s top gaming experience every time they decide to play.

Consequently, you can exchange equipment with fellow gamers, learn new skills and hacks, improve your shooting, understand the benefits of new strategies, etc. 

Available In Free-To-Play
Counter-Strike: Global Offensiveâ€™s transition into a free-to-play availability caused one of the most legendary uproars in Steamâ€™s history. However, the move turned out to be one of Valveâ€™s most excellent business decisions because it increased the player count dizzyingly. The best part is that the companyâ€™s battle royale â€“ Danger Zone â€“ is also available for free.

Accessing this mode is effortless and only requires logging into your steam account. From there, youâ€™ll see your files automatically updating on Steam along with the new mode. Consequently, playing CS:GO and Danger Zone is an excellent way to get the most out of the game without first paying for it.

I am a 54-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing Apex Legends. 
I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing Apex Legends. 
In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. 
This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son 
because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam 
account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game
 since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent some hours playing Apex Legends. 
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Playing video games 
reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought 
me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.

Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Possibly the most addictive, frustrating and satisfying game I've ever played. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better. Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If youâ€™re a Call of Duty player, youâ€™re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what itâ€™s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

In case you're unfamiliar, Counter-Strike is an entirely multiplayer experience. You can play offline against AI bots, but these are still merely simulating what it's like to play online, rather than really giving you a single-player game. The good news is that this is as good as online team-based shooters get. In the traditional game mode, there are two types of matches and two tiers of play. Casual level is for newer players and removes aspects like friendly fire and the need to purchase armor and ancillary items each round (more on that in a second). Ranked level is the original style of CS, with all the "realism" settings enabled, but it also features a comprehensive skill-based ranking system to try to balance teams and place good players with other good players.

How to enable sv_cheats commands

Before we start with the commands and CVARS, you need to enable sv_cheats commands. This is pretty simple and can be done through the developer console.

You have to be the server administrator
- Open the developer console (~)
- Type: sv_cheats 1
- Sv_cheats commands are now enabled, to disable again type â€œsv_cheats 0â€ in the console.

An aged experience. Counter Strike does not care about your aim, game sense, raw skill; it only cares about how many hours of dedicated practice and gameplay you've given it. Difficult to pickup; even more difficult to master.

DO NOT PLAY COMPETITIVE WITHOUT THE PRIME PASS. There will be no such thing as a fair match-up and you will encounter TOO MANY HACKERS. This is a warning.

When I first started playing csgo I was just a little boy. A little innocent child. After playing for 50 hours i could just feel the trauma come back to me again.  I got hooked to this game for a couple of days, but then my mother got sick. I had to quit so i could take care of her because she was the only person I had left in my life. Soon she seemed like she was getting better so i got to play once again, so instead of paying for her medical bills i told her to buy me a little pc. I played for a good ten hours, shitting myself in my little chair and firmly speaking any woman that dared to defy my orders in this silly little game, sometimes switching to other games to continue my work. One day, i was reversing my undies for 2 more days of use when my mother suddenly went into cardiac arrest while telling me to go to the bathroom because she could smell the unholy odor leaking from me. I obviously had to finish my competitive match before i could call anyone to come pick her up. After that I was sent to the foster care system, so i manipulated my foster parents into buying me a $3k laptop so i could game anywhere my young man heart desires. Now i get to switch from house to house collecting more for my little setup because every family refuses to keep me due to my overwhelming odor and my so called "oppositional defiant disorder".  I dare you to get this game. If you wish to, just

It has been a while since I have last played Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. So, coming back to CS:GO, it is a game I still enjoy and like to play. So do not worry, most of the time you will have a great match. I think the game graphics and mechanics are on a good level, no issues. Overall, game is great and the experience is good but be aware that it won't be always good as you can never get rid of cheaters from a game, one will show up at least once in a while. In the end, I would recommend this game to people and friends, quite fun.

Personally I would not recommend this game to many, but there are some people who enjoy this sort of game. For those who expect a nice fun realistic shooter this is far from it. It is heavily based on game mechanics where you ultimately have to stand still to shoot because the second you move and attempt to fire at the same time you would think you closed your eyes and sneezed at the same time while trying to shoot. For as old as the game is I give it respect for lasting so long but personally if I play a realistic game I would like the gunplay to be realistic as well and being someone who has moved and used a firearm at the same time I can say that does not happen.

CS: GO's Bomb Scenario mode is a simple, yet enjoyable, twist on the standard multiplayer FPS setup, which opens up a ton of variability in each round. Another game mode, called Hostage, flips the tables and has the Terrorists defend a hostage, while the Counter-Terrorists attempt a rescue mission. CS: GO typically gets new mission-based modes with new operations.

Counter Strike Global Offensive is a game developed by Valve.
It is extremely difficult, considering you have to wrangle teammates, manage your economy, predict your enemies economy, buy the correct shit and then aim for the head and spray correctly.

Then there is a bunch of extra shit like grenades, objectives, utility and whatever the fuck not.
It's not a game for everyone, you have to be really good with your mouse.

There's a story that someone was so good with his mouse that he became the mouse.
The mouse permanently fused into his hand. Now he has to use his other hand for certain things.

The game has multiple maps, including dust 2 which is the only map, and Mirage. But mirage...really isn't working these days.

The game will bring you so many fun experiences, like playing a game with Aldon Hilter, as he only buys a Negev and politely refuses to buy anything else. As we lose 14-16, against 4 bots.

This game is fun: In the words of a certain person, this is fucking gameplay

You can play as the the terrorists, and blow shit up while praying to the one god, or you can play as the counter terrorists, who counter terrorists' terrorizing terrorism.

Some of the guns are: The deagle, the AK-47, the P90, the AWP, and most important and deadliest of all: the decoy grenade.

Not many people know that every decoy grenade is sent from the deepest circles of hell, where the souls of the damned are burned and seared alive for all eternity.

On your journey to become better at this game, you will encounter smurfs, non-bilingual Russians, toxicity, mute people, people who make you realize that CS:GO causes metaphysical retardation, or will at least make you consider that being true.

But the worst of all: people who type "Nice Try", after you fail your fucking shitty clutch attempt.

There are a lot of mods for the game, like bunny hopping servers, 1v1 servers, surfing servers, jailbreak and a lot of other stuff.

I almost forgot to mention the skins, every single gun can be cosmetically customized if you have the money. Every skin is different and has a different price, ranging from your generic pistol skin, to a 1600 dollar knife skin.

It's a great game, it's also perfectly fucking free: So go get it.

if youre looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding apple pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup sugar
1/2 cup packed brown sugar
3 tablespoons all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/4 teaspoon ground ginger
1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
6 to 7 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples
1 tablespoon lemon juice
Pastry for double-crust pie (9 inches)
1 tablespoon butter
1 large egg white
Additional sugar

Directions: In a small bowl, combine the sugars, flour and spices; set aside. In a large bowl, toss apples with lemon juice. Add sugar mixture; toss to coat.

Line a 9-in. pie plate with bottom crust; trim pastry even with edge. Fill with apple mixture; dot with butter. Roll out remaining pastry to fit top of pie. Place over filling. Trim, seal and flute edges. Cut slits in pastry.

Beat egg white until foamy; brush over pastry. Sprinkle with sugar. Cover edges loosely with foil.

I did my research and the Ninja had the best reviews so I bought one. This is my second air fryer and to be fair I had low expectations when I got my first on an xL and high expectations when I I bought this one. Objectively the Ninja has more settings and is better looking, it does not alert you half way to turn your items over (I believe shake is a marketing thing to imply it's easy to use - turn the food over you'll get better results) also you have to pause the cooking if you pull the drawer out it will not automatically turn the fan and elements off it will keep blowing. Subjectively I think my 3 quart XL cooks food better than the Ninja, I gave it a while for the Ninja to undo this mindset as a realized my bias, but I still think the XL produces better outcomes. The Ninja might cook it a little faster, maybe more unevenly, but it works and this is part of just learning your air fryer and different foods. The Ninja is a fine looking tool I won't be returning it. The differences are slight but I have brought them under a microscope. Even if they cook the same I like a timer that sounds halfway and it's annoying I have to pause the cooking before I take the drawer out. Reliability and long term use can't say I got the XL for Christmas and it took me a while to try it out but once I did I was like oh boy I need another one for the other house so I expected the Ninja to be better. If I had to do it again I'd get another XL 3qt., The cooking pot in the 4qt ninja is about the same circumference only deeper. I got it for 70 like new vs. 60 for an xL 2 quart. I thought I was getting a lot more for a little more when I could have just saved $10 and got the 2 qt XL. It's okay (it works just fine), but I just personally prefer the xL so far.

I am a 54-year-old father, probably one of the oldest people playing CS:GO. 
I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing CS:GO. 
In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. 
This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son 
because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam 
account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game
 since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent some hours playing CS:GO. 
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Playing video games 
reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought 
me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.

Whatever Valve did recently with auto-balancing absolutely ruined the game. Besides the fact that there are dozens, if not hundreds of maps,  you are stuck playing about 20 of them. That's if you are lucky and in a decent lobby that doesn't vote the same maps over and over and over and over. Realistically, you will play Mirage, Vertigo, Cobble, and Office until your eyes bleed and you give up. There is absolutely NO REASON for this. 

Back to the auto-balancing... Seriously WTF Valve. It used to be so satisfying to absolutely dominate the other team, or even have a decent somewhat equal match. But now, EVERY SINGLE GAME WITHOUT FAIL, once one team makes it to match point, the teams are miraculously finally auto balanced and you are stuck PLAYING THE SAME SHITTY MAP FOR TWICE AS LONG. What is the logic behind making EVERY SINGLE GAME A NECK AND NECK MATCH POINT? EVERY SINGLE GAME. Your team can be ahead 7 to 1 and BOOM 7 more rounds just got added to your game our of no where. Courtesy of Valve. 

I know this game has been on the cusp of dying for a few years, especially since loot boxes took over every aspect of Valve's motivation to do anything resembling respect towards their fan-base (totally not talking about this game or Half Life, L4D, or TF2...). For years, the only thing that bumps up player count is the fan made map updates which are getting more and more rare, and offering fewer and fewer maps.

This game gets worse with every update and it is depressing. New maps are a pipe dream, playing maps you actually like is out of your control, and just when you think you are on the last round and the game is over and you can start a new map ---FINALLY A MIRACULOUS AUTO BALANCE! Have fun suddenly playing the same map for twice as long as you expected. And then once that is over, you can play the same map you just played in the previous game. 

At least most developers are upfront when they are shafting you and give you the option to unlock the content by spending more money. If you like having the vast amount of content available arbitrarily limited for NO reason with NO way to access it, this is the game for you.

Having recently hit 1K hours in the game, I feel obligated to give this game a review. With my wallet shredded into $0.03 pieces, I have to commend Valve on one of the most successful attempts to get past gambling regulations in most countries on Earth. This ponzi scheme, known as 'CS:GO', has ruined my marriage (my wife now has custody of the kids), left me homeless and spending every paycheck on crates. Some would say that it has ruined my life. Yet, I beg to differ. Although this game may have the largest amount of hackers on any game, updates dropping only when Gaben makes another billion and one-way smokes that have given me a one-way ticket to noise complaints, this game possesses something that not many games have, and it is hard to describe what that really is. All I can say however, is, if you've ever played, CSGO gives you that FPS shooter sweet-spot that every adrenaline junky craves for.

I made a severe and continuous lapse in my judgement, and I donâ€™t expect to be forgiven. Iâ€™m simply here to apologise. What we came across in the woods that day was obviously unplanned. The reactions you saw on tape were raw; they were unfiltered. None of us knew how to react or how to feel. I should have never posted the video. I should have put the cameras down and stopped recording what we were going through.
There's a lot of things I should have done differently but I didn't. And for that, from the bottom of my heart, I am sorry. I want to apologise to the internet. I want to apologise to anyone who has seen the video. I want to apologise to anyone who has been affected or touched by mental illness, or depression, or suicide. But most importantly I want to apologise to the victim and his family. For my fans who are defending my actions, please don't. I donâ€™t deserve to be defended. My goal with my content is always to entertain; to push the boundaries, to be all-inclusive. In the world live in, I share almost everything I do. The intent is never to be heartless, cruel, or malicious. Like I said I made a huge mistake. I donâ€™t expect to be forgiven, Iâ€™m just here to apologise. I'm ashamed of myself. Iâ€™m disappointed in myself. And I promise to be better. I will be better. Thank you.

Counter-Strike can be quite unfair towards honest players who do strive to reach higher levels. Reward system is poor in a sense that it does not give you game satisfaction and quite fast loose the interest. In my opinion game still holds to this day only because it is a longtime classic which has been here almost from the inception of gaming/esports. Due to this massive exposure of this game and years it has been around there is no choice for the players who want to actually make game better influence/provide feedback and be heard. Counter-Strike probably is that type of software which has reached it's development cycles to the point where modifying anything will just brake this fragile balance between those who are long time "dinosaurs" of the game and the new comers. Some of the obvious things which Valve could possibly improve and honestly should is their Anti-Cheat system, their VAC, trust factors and how their are handling bans, accidental vac bans and etc. Some part of the system are kept in secret and I it is a necessity, but certain things need to be more transparent. Other unfair point in this game is if you are skilled player and making it through quite fast 98 percent of the time you will end up a massive report abuse which will ruing your accounts trust factor and that essentially will put you into TrustFactor's Slums where all the actual cheaters, toxic personalities flourish and you will end up in a very bad in-game experience and that will either brake you or exhaust you to the point that you might never come back to this game. So if you are skilled player and looking to make a breakthrough as a player maybe pro player from zero, choose another game. If you are new to gaming and are on a lets say mid levels where your skills will not be baptised as cheating you can play this game especially if you enjoy playing just alone. If you do have a squad you constantly play with this is the easy go to game. Nevertheless, this is the all time classic and hardly anything will endanger this game as the money game valve involved with this one is just to far deep and that gives them power of choosing their resource and time allocation independently of user's feedback. If you are a new comer be aware of the world you are getting in with this game. Game is purely based on skill, execution and team work nothing more. This is not the game you want to just sit in and chill, it is its own type of pleasure and you have to understand that it is not good GFX or Good story. All about pure grinding nothing else. For the games purpose what it was made for I will give it 5 out of 5, in terms of in game experience I will give it 2 out 5. In overall i will give the game 3.5 out of 5 as a general score. However I do recommend to play this game, just try it is still on point and fun and engaging on a personal level.

Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Possibly the most addictive, frustrating and satisfying game I've ever played. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better. Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If youâ€™re a Call of Duty player, youâ€™re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what itâ€™s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

Hardly anything in â€œCounter-Strike: Global  Offensiveâ€ will surprise you, except how well it does nearly all the things audiences want and expect it to do. 

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS:GO) is a 2012 multiplayer first-person shooter developed by Valve and Hidden Path Entertainment. It is the fourth game in the Counter-Strike series. Developed for over two years, Global Offensive was released for Windows, macOS, Xbox 360, and PlayStation 3 in August 2012, and for Linux in 2014. Valve still regularly updates the game, both with smaller balancing patches and larger content additions.

The game pits two teams, Terrorists and Counter-Terrorists, against each other in different objective-based game modes. The most common game modes involve the Terrorists planting a bomb while Counter-Terrorists attempt to stop them, or Counter-Terrorists attempting to rescue hostages that the Terrorists have captured. There are nine official game modes, all of which have distinct characteristics specific to that mode. The game also has matchmaking support that allows players to play on dedicated Valve servers, in addition to community-hosted servers with custom maps and game modes. A battle-royale game-mode, "Danger Zone", was introduced in December 2018.

Global Offensive received positive reviews from critics on release, who praised the game for its gameplay and faithfulness to the Counter-Strike series, though it was criticized for some early features and the differences between the console and PC versions. Since its release, it has drawn in an estimated 11 million players per month and remains one of the most played games on Valve's Steam platform. In December 2018, Valve transitioned the game to a free-to-play model, focusing on revenue from cosmetic items.

The game has an active esports scene, continuing the history of international competitive play from previous games in the series. Teams compete in professional leagues and tournaments, and Global Offensive is now one of the largest global esports. It has been awarded "Best eSports Game" at The Game Awards 2017, The Game Awards 2019 and The Game Awards 2020 shows.

I played a lot more in my old Steam account, which was like 67 hours so I have some experience. CS:GO has a good server, as it does not take 13 minutes to launch a game. This game is free so it is basically the starting game for most steam users and is still very popular to this day. It has outdated game mechanics which only make the game more slower/competitive. It has many maps and game modes, but most players just play on DUST II and on Casual. Movement in this game is pretty slow as you cannot run so do not expect COD levels of gameplay, although it does make gameplay more slower = intense. I play on Asia server and its pretty toxic there (I do not know about other servers). My brother played this game for a long time, and he's still kind of shit at it, so..........getting good might take a decade or so. I kind of have a love and hate relationship with this game. Its somewhat frustrating and you'll mostly go your microphones blazing arguing with the other team, or you'll just enjoy it for some reason, like me. And that's all there is about this game. (you can also get steam keys from this game, which you can sell or do something with it to earn steam points)

Transformers Dark of the Moon: My favorite one because it has some of the best action sequences in the entire Franchise. The plot was actually decent had a few emotional tugs. Badass Decepticon Shockwave was here although his death was a bit anti-climatic. This was also Shia's last movie and it pretty much has a lot of what the original had and what made it so good. The only reason I put this one above Transformers 1 is because of the action! I watch these movies for entertainment and action and not as a movie critic. It's like watching Asian fighting movies without caring how bad the plot is or how bad the actors are, you're there for the fight scenes, no matter how bad the rest of the movie may be.

Transformers 1: The OG! I think all the following Transformer movies except for part 3, should have followed the template set out by this movie. It did EVERYTHING right from the action sequences to the good, but simple plot. The comedy jokes were timed well and so were the emotional set pieces. Megatron gave Prime a good fight and the final city battle is probably my favorite action sequence of the entire franchise.

Transformers: Age of Extinction: I know I know, a lot of people consider this one to be the worst or one of the worst, but I actually enjoyed it. Lockdown was such a cool transformer. Although he was a bit overpowered, he is my favorite villain behind Megatron. Everything from his alternate form to his overpowered grenades to his insane face cannon. Heck I even love his voice actor because I knew him from other movies and that made me like Lockdown all the more. Marky Mark wasn't so bad surprisingly, he was actually tolerable. I just wished they would have found a reason to make Lockdown and Megatron/Galvatron fight because that would have been an epic fight!

Transformers: Revenge of The Fallen: Even though it's second to last on my list, I didn't really hate it like sooo many people did or do. The action sequences were okay and could have been better, the best one taking place in the forest. I love fights and good action sequences, so I set a high bar when it comes to them. One thing that turns me off is a Mary Sue in these regards. Megatron gave Optimus a good fight in first movie, but here he jsut gets WRECKED. HE barely puts up a fight and I was really hoping for more. I knew Optimus would win of course, but come on! They could have made that battle a bit better.

Transformers: The Last Knight: Okay this is one is definitely the worst one and a lot of people agree with that. I'm usually very forgiving and not too harsh considering the fact the some of the movies people hated, I actually really liked. I disregard plot and only focus on entertainment and it has served me well in watching films like this, but this was just an abomination. I really tried to get into it and give it a chance, but it was just not so. The overly complicated plot goes against some of the stuff from previous films and then having Stanley Tucci play Merlin was just a WTF moment. It's like the movie knew it would suck and didn't care. Optimus turning bad could have been used for soo much more. He appears near the end when I was hoping he would make a few appearences causing trouble for the good guys, but alas another anti climatic moment strikes again! The action sequences were kind of whack and easily the worst of the series IMO. The best one was probably Bumblebee fighting Optimus. Quintessa was nothing special and the KSI Megatron body is magically gone. I wanted to see his KSI chassis in action because I actually liked how it performed in AOE, but Megatron just looked like himself without explaining what happened to that body. Like I said, I really tried to find a reason to like this movie, but it was just that bad

One of the best FPS games in the world. It is fun, competitive and sometimes stressful (bad teammates or cheaters). Sometimes I feel glad I am still playing the game, sometimes I question myself why do I keep playing this game plagued with cheaters. Basically, the game is fun but when you come across a cheater or troll/griefer/toxic people, it becomes a nightmare you wanna get the heck out of real FAST. 

For new players out there don't jump into comp right away, try all the modes, watch youtube videos, watch past PRO league tournaments, watch some popular/high rank twitch streamers, learn the maps, the callouts, the jargons, the line ups, common angles, and just have fun. Sometimes you win, sometimes you lose. It is what it is. I highly recommend the short competitive mode when you are finally ready to do some Competitive matches. Good luck, have fun!
