Valve! I just wanted to tell you one thing, I really liked your videogame, seriously, it's the most sensational thing I've played at the moment, it's a work of art, without exaggeration, it's something that, at first glance, could have been made by Da Vinci himself, his genius can be seen from miles away, not even the worst of gossips could say that we are not facing a majesty seen only once every thousand years. I have not seen in all my years of life something of this magnitude, it gives you an indescribable sensation, an immense joy despite not having done any action, a rare but fantastic feeling, something like what a breeze feels like in a hot summer, or seeing the joy of a child when opening their Christmas presents, or simply being with that person we love so much. Do not pay attention to the gossips that criticize incessantly anyone who does not fully meet all their expectations, just believe me and all those beings who consider and admire such a great work of art. There will always be people who will tell you that what you did has no value, but the secret is to ignore them, those people would give anything to have created something as magnificent as what we are seeing. Just as God in his infinite wisdom created humanity, or as a man in love creates a poem to express his deepest feelings, or as a painter creates a work of art from a time that even he does not know, this is how it was created this videogame in the same way. It may seem that I am exaggerating, I repeat, but it is not like that, not even close, I would exaggerate if I said that I am not facing an admirable, incredible creation, of a beauty of biblical proportions. In fact I am so delighted with such a contribution that I decided to write a poem about it, it is titled "my eyes thank you", here it goes: "My eyes thank you, since they have been caressed, and my feelings praise you, since have been awakened, my heart idolizes you, because you have made it dance, and my being tells you thanks for such a delicious delicacy, I will be waiting again, that you share your joy, even in the middle of the night, or on the most radiant day, just keep creating creating until your hands are heavy, so I'll tell you again, my eyes thank you." I hope you enjoyed my poem as much as I enjoyed writing it, I would tell you to enjoy it as much as I enjoyed your videogame, but I don't think there is a situation in the world that resembles such joy. To finish being brief, I wanted to thank you from the bottom of my heart, one in this life encounters situations that make him feel bad, he thinks that he is not going to find anything good these days and suddenly he finds himself with something like that, it is difficult to decide where one he is going to leave a positive review, and in fact he is already tired of reporting most of the troll reviews that he sees, since many are created by trolls and people with the desire to annoy, nothing to do with what we are observing, here one thinks quite the opposite , he simply sees it and says to himself "there must be no place on this earth, neither in heaven nor in the underworld, nor in other planets, galaxies or universes, where it is better to leave my points, I have found the true Atlantis, Although it is not a physical place, its simple beauty is enough for me not to hesitate to make such a comparison." Sometimes I wonder how much skill or how much skill it takes to be able to make a creation of this nature, sometimes I compare myself with the creators of beauties like this and I think that I am not even a simple human being, next to said creators I I feel like an ant in front of an impotent elephant, like a pawn next to a queen, like a child in front of a super hero from those comics that they like to read so much. sometimes i look up to the sky and ask "will i be able to create something that can at least compare to this videogame?" "Can I one day be as cool, as creative and talented as the creator of this?" "What does one have to do in this life to achieve such genius?" but no matter how much I ask and ask, I never get an answer. Sometimes I dream that I wake up and in front of me, next to my bed, there is a video like this, but in my dream the video has something different, the creator is me. Yes, I know it sounds crazy, something as glorious as this cannot be created by a simple being like me, but do not forget that it is only a dream. If I could make a wish, it would be that this videogame never leaves Steam, that future generations can observe its magnificence and be filled with joy with what they see. be filled with happiness, madness, passion... If all the videos in the world were like this, there would be no wars, no pain, forgetfulness, sadness. We would raise our heads and sing a song in unison, like a choir of archangels we would say: "I believe in tomorrow"...

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Counter Strike is not only one of the biggest competitive games in CSGO history but it has maintained that stature for 10 years now.

Counter Strike gives the gaming industry a competitive edge that most games cannot compare to and is one of those games where you look at the time and wonder where the time went.

Pros:
-Addicting
-Visually very appealing/Maps have amazing detail and are only getting better.
-Consistently changing the map rotation.
-Rewarding for practice and skill.
-Rank Progression is now Amazing.
-Weapon Skins and Cases constantly coming into light from the community workshop.
-Developers that actually listen.
-Tactical and Teamwork driven.
-Different game modes within the game that caters to all kinds of players.
-Community Server Browser that allows you to explore more of Counter-Strike and what it has to offer.
-Workshop maps that are created by the community
-An Anti-Cheat that actually works.
-Allows players that have reached a certain level to watch reported users that have been reported for hacking to allow the community to help stop any hackers that come into light.

Cons:
-Still on Source 1 which will hopefully change soon.
-Have not released a new operation in a while and didnt for a long period of time a few years ago.
-Toxic Players at times. (But this is for most games.)

Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Possibly the most addictive, frustrating and satisfying game I've ever played. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better. Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If youâ€™re a Call of Duty player, youâ€™re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what itâ€™s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

I just wanna start saying this game is AWESOME.
Even though most people are already very skilled at this game u still have a chance of getting good too.
First of all there is no skill based matchmaking (unless u have prime (which is like 15 dollars) ) .
So probably in your first match you will be probably fighting some weird grown man who watches hentai in his moms basement and is about 115 kg who will no scope with his awp from 100 meters, and thats because he has 10000 hours in the game. But dont quit! get a smg and go spam every one, raise hell ! 

There are lots of different mods to play going from the classic casual dust 2 other bomb defusal maps and hostage rescueing . Or if you are more expirienced u can play competitive. but i dont recommand it if you dont to cry in your pillow at 3 am. but there is also wingman a very fun 2 v 2 gamemode u either play on T 
or CT but u cant choose. its a normal defusal game but with a shorter map and only 4 persons.
And altough Cs Go its a free game there a lot of gambling sites from u can buy crates that give in game cosmetics. which i dont recommand cuz u could pay 100 dollars for some gloves and 2 weapon skins (so dont buy them !). Summing it all up cs go is very fun especially when playing with friends.

You have to know that this is my opinion for the game, so first try it and then if you don't like it, you can stop playing it.

The game is fun for atleast 5 reasons.
    1.You are able to get some drops and sell them in the market ( only if you have prime ).
    2.You can play with to 20 friends ( 10v10 )
    3.If you like battle royale games you have mod ( Danger zone for duo or SoloDuo gameplay )
    4.If you are ranked player, it has good ranked system.
    5.if you are not like the ranked players you can go to the community servers.

You need to know about FRIENDLY communication whit others some basic things like:
    GG / gg - Good game
    GH / gh - Good half

You will see and toxic communication like:
    Aggressive or abusive words 
    Ez / noob / trash and more- means that you are bad at the game ( ignore that one that talks like that to you and if you want report him )
    Tea-bagging- part of the trash-talking but if they cannot communicate with you

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a Virtual Youtuber empire for over a year now and using me as his recruiter. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my Live2D knowledge to recruit talents, which he would then hire using his connections in the Japanese utaite world. Connections that he made through his career with Niconico. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small indie channel could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Motoaki "Yagoo" Tanigo, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Yagoo threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Yagoo had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Yagoo flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Yagoo was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Riku Tazumi , he plotted to kill Yagoo, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Cover Corp, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my vtubing activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is! (:  :)

Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is, as it always has been for this series, the greatest way to learn where you should have gone, what you shouldn't have done, and how you could have done better. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently, they are always getting better.

Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If youâ€™re a Call of Duty player, youâ€™re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what itâ€™s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.

For the uninitiated, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a small-scale, team-based first-person shooter with permanent death. When a counter-terrorist kills a terrorist planting explosives in a classic Defusal match, or a CT escort swallows a sniper round in Hostage Rescue, the victim is dead for good and doesn't respawn until the next round. As such, players on both sides must exercise skill and care. The bomb objective, meanwhile, gives everyone a purpose. Of course matches end when everyone on a team is dead, but a clever and coordinated terrorist team will give the CTs the slip, plant their bomb, and protect the bomb site. Between rounds, everyone spends earned cash on better gear and guns, and the cycle continues.

Pieces of the Counter-Strike formula are dated at this point, but the superb heart and soul of Global Offensive is timeless. Teams are small, guns are lethal, and rounds are short. There's an addictive just-one-more-round quality to it, because there's a constant desire to do better than last time, to earn a satisfying kill, or to win in a new way. Call of Duty and Battlefield vets will wonder why they can't sprint to escape enemy fire or look down the iron sights to improve aim; Counter-Strike players will feel like they walked into their redecorated home. Certain map redesigns will catch hardcore fans off guard, but the changes are for the best -- the underpass choke point in de_dust, for instance, has a new escape route.

Even in the face of genre evolution, Global Offensive doesnâ€™t care to adapt. CSGO is so dedicated to Counter-Strike's aging ideals despite market and trend changes that it brute-forces its way to success. Part of what makes it such an engaging competitive game is that killing in Global Offensive requires a wholly different skill set than other shooters. Everyone is limited to what they have and can see, with little room for character modification or on-the-fly advantages. Running and gunning is a useless play style, even if you've bought a helmet and kevlar that round, to the point that someone standing still is more likely to score the kill. Walking, crouching, or standing are your best bets to reduce the inaccurate spray of machine-gun fire.

Consequently, killing in Global Offensive feels good. There's a sickening sensation to dropping someone dead because you know they're not coming back. It's also satisfying knowing you used limited resources to play smarter than your victim. If players aren't watching corners, providing covering fire, or using smoke grenades and flashbangs, they're more likely to take a headshot from a more delicate and patient triggerman. The desire to experience that distinct feeling is a strong motivator to keep playing, even when you're getting steamrolled by an obviously better team.

If you've played Counter-Strike before, Global Offensive probably sounds a whole lot like Counter-Strike. Like Counter-Strike: Source before it, Global Offensive exists simply to modernize the look of the classic competitive shooter, while doing little to disrupt the core form and function. At the same time, it does enough to color outside the lines of tradition to justify your time and effort.

Fire is one of the most interesting new combat variables. Molotov cocktails and incendiary grenades either roast groups of guys or force them in another direction. Flames are a useful distraction or scare tactic, too. They're particularly useful during Demolition matches, which focus the fight at a single bomb site rather than giving terrorists two to pick between. The new and modified maps in this mode aren't as big as classic Counter-Strike arenas â€“ entire sections have been cut off to direct teams toward a central location â€“ but their thoughtful design is as intricate as ever. The Lake map is a standout -- there's a wide open yet densely populated yard around the bomb site, which is inside a sizable lakeside home with plenty of vantage points and hiding spots. To separate Demolition from Defusal, players can't buy between rounds. Instead, it takes a cue from the other new mode, Arms Race, in which each kill unlocks another weapon instantly. The better you do, the more you have to switch up the way you play, and because Demolition is so fast you'll need to be quick on your feet.

Unlike other game types, Arms Race allows for respawns. It's the most chaotic and care-free mode in Global Offensive, with players throwing caution to the wind for the sake of climbing the kill ladder as quickly as possible. It's a shame there are only two maps in Arms Race -- a problem that will more likely persist on consoles than PC.

If you have the option, playing the PC version is unquestionably the best way to experience Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Mods, mouse and keyboard, and the usual PC-only options are better than the ports. Plus, Valve is much better about long-term PC support -- it abandoned Team Fortress 2 on consoles, and Portal 2's level editor was PC exclusive. If you prefer to play on consoles, Global Offensive is the same great game

This is my 1st review. The choice was easy, It had to be Counter-Strike. As a gamer of 25+ years I'd say that everyone should try this game at least once. You have to. Especially now that is offered for free. The game is VERY satisfying.
Offers different modes, and if you can (and feel like it) you can spend on customization too. Simple as that.
The entire series since the the game was a mod of Half-Life back in 1998 have been very entertaining and I got to witnessed this playing all over the globe. From small internet cafe's to large internet clubs with 200+ PCs and an entire city competing through the servers. If you stick to the official servers - obviously - you will won't see any hacks and such.
At the end of the day, never forget this. It is just a game, to entertain your time. Nothing more, nothing less. Sometimes you will win, sometimes you will lose, and most importantly, try to not get anything seriously.

It's a great game. players are sometimes rude but you can just turn the sound off. to get cool skins for your guns i think the best way is to buy prime or just buy crates themselves. the people in voice chat are weird. one time i was playing during a literal THERAPY SESSION. to actually be able to rank up or level up in this game you have to first buy prime and them play some games. there is absolutely no PAY TO WIN and if you do spend money on this game, its mostly going to be for customisation and skins. during the first hour or so you might struggle even to get a single kill but after you start to get familiar with the aiming and controls, you can beat the daylights out of the opponent team. this game is also focused on the gamemode Defuse which not everyone will enjoy but because of the no respawn it feels more like a team deathmatch. csgo is really a sit down for 2 hours and grind game because if you have a close match it could take up to 30 mins to finish and if you're planning to play multiple then you'll be sitting there for a couple hours. like valorant, there is no aming to guns other than an assult rifle and sniper so you have to crouch to aim better. also like valorant, there is a money system and at the start of every round you buy guns and grenades.

short version: rude players, pay to customise, people in voice chat are weird, pay to be able to rank up, first hour or so is hard, no pay to win, Defuse, long matches, not many scoped guns, money system.

in my opinion csgo is a great game but it might not be for everyone so i hope this review helps you decide if you want to play it or not.

Still the best competitive FPS to date.
If you love high skill required games this game is for you.

Pros:
* Every gun has a set spray pattern
* Everything you do from throwing grenades, movement and position is required to master if you want to reach the top.
* Lots of community servers b-hop, surf, prop hunt etc
* Got all the game modes you could wish for.
* huge player base
* One of the best anti cheats, that does not require you to put chinese spyware on your computer.
* Marketplace for skins
* Higher skill curve than valorant in almost everyway and more community based.

Cons:
* No 128 tick server in matchmaking yet, This forces you to play on community based platforms and servers like FACEIT.
* Some cheaters if your trust factor is bad and you do not have prime.

One of the best if not the best tactical competitive FPS games out there.
CS is as old as half-life and it's mechanics & formulas have been battle-tested over & over.
Still, there are a lot of stuff that I personally wish were different.

Ideas for a better game:

1- Randomized maps
memorizing maps & particular positions & strats in them plays a huge part in this game.
in an ideal world, each map should be semi-randomly generated so that grinders who've played each map a million times & memorized shooting & nade-throwing spots would have less of an edge.

2- randomized spray patterns
thou shall not reward grinding

2- more dynamic surroundings, semi-open world
at this day and age, traditional cs maps induce claustrophobia. manipulation of environment, bringing down walls, setting traps, throwing stuff, ... could be a breath of fresh air if the game engine supports it.

3- crypto-economy, tokens, assets, ... secured on an open system for incentivizing content-creation by users could take development a long way. Imagine being paid actual valuable tokens exchangeable for items & ... after each win instead of non-sensical experience points & badges.

Been playing this since my freshman year of high school up until now that I'm in the military with little spare time. This game has changed so much and so little at the same time and that's not a bad thing. Growing with the community as a person and watching the game develop, it's a rare thing to be a part of. I love this game, even if I am not the best, not even close. It's defined pc gaming with tight and precise controls. Over the top tactics and an incredibly steep skill curve. I can see myself well into the future being in the mood for some CSGO matches. I hope we both make it there. <3

I am a 53 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing CSGO. 
I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started playing Apex Legends. 
In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. 
This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son 
because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam 
account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game
 since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent some hours playing CSGO. 
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Playing video games 
reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought 
me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.
I am also now getting in playing ranked and its so much fun :)

Counter Strike: Global Offensive is a game developed by Valve. It's extremely difficult considering you have to wrangle teammates, manage your economy, predict your enemies' economy, buy the correct sh*t then aim for the head and spray correctly. And there's a bunch of extra sh*t like grenades, objectives, utility and whatever the f*ck not. It's not a game for everyone, you have to be really good with your mouse. There's a history that someone was so good with his mouse he became the mouse, the mouse permanently fused into his hand. Now he has to use his other hands for certains things. This game has multiple maps, including Dust II, wich is the only map, and Mirage, but Mirage really isn't working these days. This game will bring you so many fun experiences like playing a game with Aldon Hilter, as he only buys a Negev and unpolitely refuses to buy anything else. As we lose 14-16 against four bots. This game is fun. In the words of a certain person, this is f*cking gameplay. You can play as the terrorists and blow sh*t up while praising the one God or you can play as the Counter terrorists, who counter the terrorists' terrorizing terrorism. Some of the guns are the Desert Eagle, the Ak-47, the AWP and the most important and deadliest of all, the decoy grenade. On your journey to become better on this game you'll encounter smurfs, non bilingual russians, toxicity, mute people, people that'll make you realize that CSGO causes metaphysical retardation, or at least will make you consider that being true, but the worst of all, people who type "NT" after you f*cking fail your sh*tty clutch attempt.

My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

Counter-Strike:Global Offensive is a game developed by Valve, it is extemely difficult considering you have to wrangle your teammates, manage your economy, predict your enemies' economy, buy the correct sh*t then aim for the head and spray correctly; then there is a bunch of extra sh*t like grenades, objectives, utility and whatever the fu*k not; it's not a game for everyone, you have to be really good with your mouse, there is a story that someone was so good with his mouse, he bacame the mouse, the mouse permanently fused into his hand, now he has to use his other hand for certain things; the game has multiple maps including Dust 2, which is the only map, and Mirage but Mirage just really isn't working these days; the game will bring you many fun experiences like playing with Aldon Hilter as he only buys a Negev and unpolitely refuses to buy anything else as we lose 14-16 against 4 bots; this game is fun in the words of a certain person this is fu*king gameplay: you can play as the terrorists and blow sh*it up while praising the one god or you can play as the counter terrorists who counter the terrorists terrorizing terrorism; some of the guns are: the Deagle, the AK-47, the P90, the AWP, but the most important and deadliest of all is the decoy grenade, not many people know that every Decoy grenade is sent from the deepes circle of hell where the souls of the damned are burned and seared alive for all eternity; on your journey to become better at this game you will encounter smurfs, non-billingual russians, toxicity, mute people, people who make you realise that CS:GO causes metaphysical retardation or at least will make you conider that being true, but the worst of all the people who type "Nice Try" after you fu*king fail your shi*ty clutch attempt; there are a lot of mods for the game like bunny hopping servers, 1v1 servers, surfing servers, Jailbreak, and a lot of other stuff; I almost forgot to mention the skins, every single gun can be cosmetically customized if you have the money, every skin is different and has a different price ranging your generic pistol skin to a 1600$ knife skin; it's a great game, it's also perfectly fu*king free, so go get it.

You sit on the toilet to poop, but the poop never stops coming out of your butt. You have to start flushing the toilet every two minutes to keep up. You try to pinch your butt closed but that makes your insides hurt. You call 911. The paramedics call for doctors. The doctors call for specialists. The story trends on Twitter. Your septic tank fails. People form a cult. Your toilet is finished. Volunteers arrive with buckets and shovels. The poop accelerates. You are moved to a stepladder with a hole in the top step. The poop accelerates. The shovelers abandon the buckets and shovel directly out the window. The poop accelerates. One of the workers falls over and can't free himself. The poop accelerates. The force now propels you forward and upward. Vigil goers grab at your legs. The poop ignites from their candles. The Facebook live event hits 5 million viewers. The poop accelerates. You are 30 feet in the air. The fire engulfs the vigil and your house. 60 feet. The poop accelerates. You try to close up shop but your butthole disintegrated long ago. 120 feet up. Your house explodes. The poop accelerates. 1000 feet. You are now tracked on radar. You try to change your angle of ascent but you should have thought of that way earlier. The poop accelerates. 4,000 feet. 30,000 feet. You no longer take in enough oxygen to sustain consciousness. 60,000 feet. CNN is reporting on all the world records you've broken. 200,000 feet. You are no longer alive.

The game is good really good, bu only if you have 4 friends to play with, or you don't have Prime and don't care about the ranks.
If you do care about ranks, and you do it alone then you will have a really hard time. Before the Matchmaking update I was Silver 4, currently I am unranked (haven't played since). The time it took me to get to S4 solo queue is about 220 hours, and even though I am bad I think that I am not this bad. Getting to Global or FaceIt lvl. 10 would take even longer, so I only recommend CS to players who could make a 4 or 5 stack or to those with a lot of time.

I really recommend playing this game. Its a first person shooter game and the game has various objectives you have to complete in order to win a round or a whole match. To win a round as a "terrorist" you have to either eliminate all players from the opposing side or plant the bomb and wait until it goes off. The bomb takes a while until it goes off so you have to protect it from the players of the other side because they can defuse it and win the round. As a "counter terrorist" your mission is to either defuse the bomb, eliminate all threats without the bomb being placed, or wait until the time runs off.

This game sucks, you rage, you get pissed, you get confused and dazed by the fact that some guy snipes you from across the map. In my opinion i have the most fun with shotguns and smgs (i'm not bad at the game smh), some weapons (*cough* awp *cough*) are incredibly broken. Auto sniper? yeah it may be the 2nd best gun in the game but only losers play Auto snipers, real chads (like myself) use Mag7 for everything, Sniping? Mag 7. Camping? Mag 7.  ( for t side, don't even bother with the Sawed off) this game, i've been playing it just shy of 3 years, why did i say it's shit? because i'm angry at it. all in all 10/10 would rush b again.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a multiplayer first-person shooter video game in which teams of terrorists battle to perpetrate an act of terror (bombing, hostage-taking) while counter-terrorists try to prevent it (bomb defusal, hostage rescue). The series began on Windows in 1999 with the release of the first game, Counter-Strike. It was initially released as a modification ("mod") for Half-Life that was designed by Minh "Gooseman" Le and Jess "Cliffe" Cliffe before the rights to the mod's intellectual property were acquired by Valve, the developers of Half-Life, who then turned Counter-Strike into a retail product released in 2000. Counter Strike: Global Offensive may just be the finest game of our generation, with balanced weapons, exiting gameplay in which both teams may attack and defend, allowing non-boring gameplay. CS:GO is unique with features such as spray patterns, a pistol round, etc. It really innovates the first person shooter genre. It is no way near pay to win, with skins allowing no competitive advantage, although in the end everyone buys at least one or two skins. In conclusion, CS:GO is a great game, and every human being capable of using a computer should at least try the game once. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

This is a game that gets satisfying to play before it gets fun to play.

You spend a whole lot of time developing basic skills like moving around the map, controlling your shots, and telling your team what you see so they can act on it.

If you're not sure where you're going, are missing your shots, and don't feel like the team is communicating, it's probably not going to feel like a fun time.  Don't panic just yet, that's totally normal, you're still learning.

At some point you will get the basics down and can jump into competitive.  I recommend giving this a try as soon as possible -- with the pressure turned up, this means your actions have meaning in the game.  

You will care what happens because your team cares what happens, and they will for sure let you know if you're helping or not.  And every so often in competitive the algorithm gets it right.  It finds two teams who put everything they've got against each other and its not clear who is going to win.

Someone has to dig deep beyond what they thought they could do and unleash the beast within to win the game for their team.  If you stick with it that'll be you and you'll figure out why people love this game.

It's a fun you have to work for, can be a bumpy ride along the way, and definitely worth the trip

CSGO is one of the most popular first-person shooters out there, but it's not without its problems. For starters, the game is extremely unbalanced. The AK-47 is way too powerful and the M4A4 is way too weak. This makes for some very one-sided matches.  Another big issue is the game's economy. It's extremely hard to get enough money to buy decent weapons, and even when you do, you'll likely get destroyed by someone with a better weapon. This makes the game very frustrating, and it's not uncommon to see people quitting matches early because they're so fed up.  The community is also a big problem. There's a lot of toxicity and it's very easy to get banned for no reason. The matchmaking system is also flawed, often putting people of vastly different skill levels against each other.  Overall, CSGO is a fun game, but it's far from perfect. If you're looking for a competitive shooter, you might want to give it a pass.

I've never played a game that busts my nuts the way CSGO does. If you play this game, you will eat shit. That pixel you saw a mile away? That's a person ... and now you're heads blown off. Hear footsteps? Don't even bother to brace yourself ... people here have the most ungodly reaction time I've ever seen. In a way tho ... thats what makes this game great. The gratification of winning a game, getting a kill, or even just taking 7 seconds longer to eat shit ... you'll feel like you've really progressed in life (but you haven't). 

TL;DR: Ye the game's alright. Just don't play it if you're looking for a reason to jump off a bridge.

Well, after 900 hours of my life spent on this game, I can say that it is NOT worth playing. People love to talk about how fair and balanced it is but in reality, only about 6 guns EVER get used because the rest of them are fucking awful so youre basically stuck playing the exact same formulaic game over and OVER. Here's how a typical win goes: as a terrorist, you dick around for 4 rounds until everyone can afford AKs and then youre basically unstoppable and win as many rounds as it takes to get to the half. Then as a CT, the other team is so demoralized that they dont even try and you win out. If you have to START as ct... well then youre really fucked. Better hope your team wins at least 13 rounds because if not, T side will come back 98 percent of the time because of how good and cheap their guns are! So basically to win you need a few things to happen: A, win the coin toss and start as T. B: Luck out with teammates. and C: pray there isn't some nerd on the other team who has 4k cs hours and another 6 in R6.

The game has much much more value to someone who wants to play this game competitively OR for someone who can actively play with friends often. Or at least at this point. It was probably more fun when it was introduced.

If you are into either of those, have a go!

I see more value playing with people I know and I can't honestly say I'd ever be good enough to play this well. I guess that's sort of the challenge?
That being said it can be satisfying to do well in the game but, as many others have noted, it can have it's fair share of cheaters and also has it's fair share of annoying people screaming obscenities (etc) over microphones/text either with you or at you depending on your perspective. 
If you're down/fine with all that please, have a go. It is free after all. I just struggle to find it very enjoyable most times without friends.

All negatives aside...
It's a solid FPS without a doubt and I'm sure many people can enjoy it and block out the rest. I mostly just catch myself playing it mindlessly when I'm bored OR when one of my friends if they want to join me.

Now it's more of a time waster if you're not trying to actively get better. And, with the number of people who play constantly and with an amount of cheaters to add on top of it it just... gets old fast.
If you don't take it seriously and can have fun with it I'd say it's worth it. Otherwise you'll be behind the curve of the regular community (and will likely be berated for it) OR you'll find yourself opposite a cheater and no one likes being cheated. Don't say you weren't warned!

Game has more people hacking than actually just playing the game (trigger bots are the most common, most are just blatantly wall hacking as well). It's quite literally become a cesspool for cheaters to just compete against one another. Game used to be fun, I dumped hundreds of hours in back in 2016-2018 and managed to make it to LEM. Found the higher ranks to not be as enjoyable due to the sheer amount of spinbotters I was meeting (usually played in the AM). Took about a 4 year break, only to find that the game is in a even worse state than before. It's quite literally unplayable now. Every casual game has 4-5 hackers per team. Every ranked game there'll be at least one on your team and the enemy team. Just sucks the fun out of the game, and makes it pointless to play. Overall this game made some great memories for me, but the cons far outweigh the pros for me now. Cyka Blyat.

Undoubtedly the most complete game in the Counter-Strike saga. Over the years, several projects have failed for the evolution of Counter-Strike 1.6, but there is no doubt that Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is here to stay, innovating not only the game system, but also the contribution and participation of players. in the Steam and Counter-Strike community. Graphically speaking, the game still doesn't quite compete with the top FPS that everyone loves, but it has gained a very good graphical overhaul. Another point worth mentioning is the game's menus, which have been simplified and ensure ease of use. It should be noted that the game is constantly being updated, with updates being released periodically to respond to problems reported by players. In addition to bug fixes, updates bring with them epic news. From update to update the news is amazing! The downside to mention is the competitive mode. Where even today there is no effective anti-cheat that ends with "cheats".
In short, it's an epic game! A renewed classic!!

Counter-Strike isn't like other games. I'm not sure if I'm qualified to speak on all of it only being Legendary Eagle right now with over 1.1k hours. This game is and will always be active and a classic. It has personally helped me combat depression and given me hours of enjoyment. CSGO is easy to learn, and very hard to master. There are many minute details you need to practice and know: economy, spray controls, maps, movement, nade line-ups, and team play. It takes a very long time to master this game, and as someone with over 1000 hours, I know I'm still no where close. Don't let that deter you from the game! There are many aspects of the game to enjoy, even for people who are just looking for casual play. I personally like Flying Scoutsman and Arms Race, which are very fun if you want to casually kill some time and have fun. CSGO is not just a game, it's the high society of gamers. People all around the globe gather to play CSGO. From the memes of using a "SWAG 7", or an auto sniper, to "RUSH B", it will always be a culture that unites players across different regions. I love this game.

This game causes me unimaginable pain. 10/10.

In CS:GO, you play the role of a hot masculine special agent, whitch objective it is to either defuse a bomb planted by the terrorists or plant the bomb as a said terrorist. In this game, you encounter a healthy amount of cultural and political diversity, from countries such as russia, poland, middle east and russia and middle east and poland etc. These people, especially from russia, are very open-minded and accepting of whoever you are. From my experience, they really like the LGBTQ+ community and people from Germany. It is a great game to meet new friends from many different countries like russia, russia, russia and russia. You can also improve your language skills just by listening to the lovely sweet conversations by your mates in the CS:GO voice chat.
So anyway, wo also gets a stiffy when dominated by a russian cheater with a masculine, bone deep voice or is it just me? I mean just the thought of me getting absolutely obliterated by a muscular north-eastern Siberian young man who fights with bears on a regular basis. The thought of you being stuck in one lobby with him with no way out because your mates won't surrender. The warm and sweaty feeing of helplessness does really drive me INSANE ( in a good way///) I usually inseminate the underside of my desk after the eight round because i am a weak ass but i really wish i could go for longer. Because of my kink, i wake up every morning flaming with ecxitement to hop on a fresh round of de_office and try my luck. But because of my relatively high trust factor and the recent effectiveness of VAC (curse this damned programm) i can no longer have fun 8x a day :(. It is really hard to encounter cheaters nowadays which really disappoints me. Sometimes i really think about quitting the game because there are too few cheaters. I really wish valve would do something to combat the frequent banning of cheaters. In my opinion, they should remove VAC and the overwatch system, because they are too effective and ruin my fun.
I think i might have lost my way, but i shall continue. Just hearing the ï·½ ï·½ from your lovely arab teammate makes you feel like you're in another country. I recommend playing CS:GO with an open voice chat, especially if you have mental health problems and/or suicidal thoughts, because your teammates and even your enemies will be very supportive and help you seek appropriate help for your problems. The CS:GO community is a wonder of its own and worth exploring. Playing CS:GO is like balm for the soul. It helps you find inner peace and guides you on your path to your better self.
CS:GO is the cool breeze from the west, the crackling of the autumn-colored leaves under your boots, the sparkling of cool water in the summer heat, the reflections of light on a sweaty, muscular male body, the Creme Ã  la Creme of video games by far.

CSGO, a game that holds a special place in my heart. When I first encountered CSGO for the first time at a young age(im sad to say it was the roblox version) I instantly fell in love with it. I had played other shooters and this one was something different to me. It was fast paced, but balanced. It was not one of those games a brain dead person could excel at, it was perfection. I have played CSGO for 5 years now on different accounts and although it is always the same basic idea, every match I have played was different. CSGO is one of the few rare games I have played were I never get bored of it, I always find myself coming back to it. I have gone though weeks of terrible performance yet I still find pleasure in the game. CSGO is the game that never dies, because the community cannot let this game go. It is too perfect, the best FPS ever created. For those of you who are wondering wether to play this game or buying prime, you should do it. Even with cheaters, you will still come back to this game and to me, this game is priceless.

Like with any competitive multiplayer game, thereâ€™s a big market for cheats in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Valveâ€™s timeless first-person shooter has an incredibly high skill ceiling, and some players will resort to using CS:GO cheats or hacks to make their way to the elusive rank of Global Elite.

It can be tempting to cheat when youâ€™re constantly dying to better players, but doing so can lead to some pretty bad repercussions. If you value your Steam account and the ability of playing online multiplayer games with friends, you might want to reconsider. With permanent CS:GO bans and VAC bans on the line, the risks seriously outweigh the benefits of downloading a dodgy script you found online.

I know everybody knows about CS. But there are a few Glaring problems I face with the game. I get that I am in the minority. There is fun to be had in this game, so If you are interested play it.

First off Wallhackers are Prolific. Every day I have had to deal with them though Admittedly I only played three days. It is a free game so some hackers are to be expected. But I have not seen any of them get dealt with.

Second, some gun damage just does not make sense. An Mp5sd doing about 5-13 hp a hit. Wow that is small especially when you consider the AK47 can two shot people that means 50 Damage like 1300$ more and you can literally just two shot people. Why do you even have the option. That is not balance that is just, stupid. 
- My solution I would have Equalize damage a bit more price reflects mobility, Map response, Magazine size. 

Third and this is by far the most annoying thing to me. How bullet spread works and Always against my favor. The amount of times I have watched people full sprint one shot headshot me is over the reasonable threshold. But I can be crouched and have a person in the retical box, and Still not get a single shot to hit them does not matter if it is Full auto, Burst, or Single. Yes I know how the recoil works. Yes I adjust for it. But my bullets just magically disappear, or do Literally 5 damage.
It literally describes the Bullet spread at full auto as  "The distance at which the spread stays within the size of a dinner plate." This is not accurate. At 5 meters the MP5 Will miss an elephant, or a barn maybe even a 747 Boeing airplane. Ahh maybe that is just the bullets magically disappearing when I fire the gun. idk.
 
-Solution. Get more recoil spreads, as for the game making bullets disappear on me, I have no solution I was probably cursed by some witch or something.

I switch to the AK47/M1, and They are literally easy mode in comparison to the lower guns. Ok, Power weapon I am fine with that I guess. But now I wonder Why can people full sprint and always hit me with every shot. RNG, The fact that the fire pattern is always the same? Ok. That just ends up being an Unpleasant experience.

Last problem I have with the game is Ping, lag, Latency. Some people no matter what their ping is always have an advantage. It just takes their actions sometimes even seconds ahead of yours. I emptied an entire Magazine into a guy this last round only to die watch the replay and see that on his screen I shot nothing and he Full dash Whipfired at me and one shot me. 

The rest of these are just nitpicks. 
1. Why allow holding different weapons to change your speed. It seems like an accidental byproduct that never got fixed. Why is it not a cumulative of all your gear? I just do not understand and it seems lazy and something for decent players to abuse.

2. Also some of the map designs are just... Fever dreams. You ever hear of the Winchester mansion? That is how some of the maps feel, others are all right at best. The Highrise under construction. I swear if you submitted that blueprint to be built you would be fined by the client and institutionalized. I know it is a video game. Also screw the RULE of Three Paths in map design.

3. Shotgun distances. Just screw off. Literally be within 3 feet or your shotgun does nothing. Dammit go pay to do some clay shooting with a shotgun. That Target load is the shortest range standard 12 gauge Shotgun load and still reaches out to 150 feet with a decent shotgun. You firing buckshot that dissapears after three feet is just a damn game sin in this day and age. Balance be damned the game does not have any anyways.

4.Why be so afraid of foilage? There is no grass, No tree branches to hide your presence a little bit. You can not blend in you ARE the Scenery in this game. Also no Prone? Ok I guess.

Anyways I have awful luck in video games so RNG on where bullets hit or if they even get counted will be different and better for you. But as far as I am concerned I do not know how people take this game seriously with the amount of Jank I have seen. And I am not really expecting them to change anything in this game, after all it is one of the most beloved games still going. I recognize I am an outlier so yeah. All the best in your games.

I never thought I'd see the day where I physically hate to play CSGO(as of 8/8/2022) but apparently today's that day. The netcode sucks, the random lag spikes from the game on my beast machine of a built desktop rig suck(overclocked core i7 8700k, RTX 3080 Founders, 32gb DDR4, 1TB NVMe SSD, 1k watt platinum EVGA PSU), and the community in servers are overall dogshit trash sweatlords who only play CS and nothing more.
I tried doing one single competitive game to place my skill level, and lost 8-15 while top fragging. 

This game sucks lmao. Honestly wish they would've fixed alot of glaring issues years ago(128 tick servers WOULD HAVE BEEN FUCKING NICE JUST SAYING) but apparently the millions upon millions of dollars Gaben has racked up clearly isn't enough to update what used to be one of if not the most popular shooter of all time.

My disappointment is immeasurable, and my day for gaming has been ruined.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing CSGO. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing CSGO and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing CSGO. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. CSGO reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

If you have never played Counter Strike: GO before, it's worth giving it a shot despite its age. If you have played it and decided to leave for whatever reason, know that not much has changed. CS: GO is still a solid multiplayer FPS with a good variety of weapons, maps, and modes. However, despite the Panorama UI update, some maps are starting to look dull compared with those in more modern titles such as PUBG and Overwatch. And although CS: GO's esports following contributes to its prolonged success, the player community is not as welcoming as others.

A childhood game since version 1.6 that we loved to enter with friends and decide who was the best shooter. In the Global Offensive version, we started creating teams and playing more intelligent games trying to win over others.
However, if your nervous system is not too strong and you did not go there just to have fun, then do not go there.
A huge number of cheats with which the developers seem to be trying to fight, but all without success. If there is no cheater in your game, then most likely there will be one or more toxic players who will blame others for everything and spoil the mood and thirst for victory.
Every time I entered this game, I was disappointed in it.
However, like other childhood games, it forever took a place in my heart, breaking it again and again.

There's also a few minigames to play if you want a more casual experience.

Since the game has moved to free-to-play, I've noticed a large increase in the general toxicity as well as hacking(lots more overwatch opportunities). Until the community becomes more heavily moderated, I would suggest not letting children play unless you are okay with them hearing racial or homophobic slurs on a daily basis. Even if a user does get banned, they are free to create a new account, this will be a tough problem to solve until IP banning comes into greater use.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories. h

Pros:
-many game modes
-good mechanics/physics
-great competitive maps
-great skins/stickers/graffitis
-great xp reward system
-great and creative operation missions
-great battle royal mode


Cons:
-toxic community
-too many cheaters
-toxic environment
-lack of constructive communication between teammates/opponents
-lack of anti-cheat software like FACEIT or ESEA
-free to play

Needed Updates
-cooldowns for toxic voice and audio messages
-one account per individual verified by with their unique ID
-anti-cheat software which is launched before the game
-small price online and offline tournaments for community players
-1v1 game mode with many maps

This game is a fine mixture between civilized political conversations with dangerously drunk russians, and being that drunk russian, having a political conversation. I love the community. Even if they are socially unacceptable within our perpetual borders of verbal society, they always make me love this game even more. Every time I fire up CS:GO, I just sit back, relax and get wallbanged through the double doors in DUST 2 as AT. No one on my team would care, because this is a more evolved community than games like Valorant. In CS:GO, people are happily toxic, and Valorant players, they are intoxicatingly toxic. What differentiates Valorant and CS:GO is that Valorant branches off of the League of Legends community, who are all a part of the RIOT Games family. They are known for their toxicity, which is their biggest problems. I always enjoyed the gameplay of Riot's games, but their community is so not hallal mode. Counter-Strike's similarity with Valorant was angry 12-year olds screaming about getting flashed by tryhards' lineups. This is easily avoided by simply playing unrated, or just getting good when playing competitive.

Counter-Strike also allows alot more diversity through your firearm choice. There are always different ways to ddeal with enemy players having superior aim. You could buy a MAG-7 and be called a ***** when you kill an enemy player. Or save up for machine guns, snipers etc. There is so much about the game to be enjoyed. You can always play with friends at 02:00 and just have a good vibe throughout the night, because there is litteraly nothing that can ruin that type of mood. You run into hackers? kick him, or find a new server. You can mess with your mates by vote-kicking them, or voting for a map they don't like. There is no limits to your fun, and definitely worth investing several hundreds, and maybe thousands of hours in!

As a somewhat seasoned CS:GO player, I WOULD suggest newcomers to the FPS genre to play this game, as it will give you the most toxic, grindy experience one could enjoy. This game will not only help you dial in your aim and game awareness, but you will come out of your CS:GO experience a changed man. All jokes aside, this game is a great launchpad for those who are looking to get 'better' at playing FPS's, as this is the ultimate challenge to ones skill. Good luck!

Great game playing with friends but playing solo can be very boring, especially if you don't have prime. Even playing with friends and not having prime can be a little bit boring because of cheaters every game/every other game. The only time I really get mad is if I die to something stupid, cheaters (uncommon w/ prime), or if my teammates are yelling racial slurs at me because im going negative by 1 kill (ex. 1-2). But in general the game is good 8/10 without prime, 10/10 with prime!

Good afternoon,

I'm writing this message with the great understanding that it may not even be read, but I'm going to try

The new rank update in cs go gave me hope for a profound change in the player selection system and a fundamental fix to all ranks, but numerous games with the new update have shown me that the game has not just become unbearable, but horrible.

The problem is that literally every game I'm up against serious ranks that I still have a long way to go (I provide screenshots). If such problems in the previous version of cs go were rare, now it happens literally every game.

This ruins all my impressions of the game and I literally do not want to go into it anymore, in destroyed not only the fundamental balance of the game, but the very essence of competition game

This game is like meth but not in a good way. You'll be up for hours tense and paranoid. You'll get that rush of winning a game or getting a nice ace to get that dopamine going but its short lives and far inbetween. You'll eventually want to quit and stop playing but its hard to quit like meth. You'll keep coming back like an abused girlfriend to her abuser. You'll hate this game and constantly talk bad about but yet not stop playing. Even if you quit for an extended period of time, just like a drug addict getting back into old habits, you'll reinstall and or open the game play one and fully relapse. I wish you the best of luck if you plan on buying this game or even if you re-buying it just because your using a new steam account and i'm sorry to you I truly am I hope one day even for my self we can break this viscous cycle of swearing this game off at night just to open it back up in the morning.

Fun game overall, though it may at times consume too much of your day time.

No wonder CS is 20+ years old. This game is so addictive. I was never really into gaming but this game changed my opinion. This is one of the most accurate FPS games ever made with 128 tick servers. This game requires passion, dedication, hardwork, skill & a lot of practice because every pixel counts when you trigger you gun.

When you will play on low tier like Silver & Gold Nova you may lose many games because of your teammates. They may do basic mistakes like Run & Gun, Team Flash etc. But never rage on them. Always remember we used to do the same basic mistakes when we were beginners. I know this game involves lot of emotion but keep your calm & make sure to teach the beginners. Our community is already toxic, lets not make it more.

You win or you learn, you never lose.

CS will never die.

I'm a 45 year old parent, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single parent raising my son who is now 14 years old. My son got this game for Christmas 2021 from his uncle so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me as it was already hard to find ways to spend time with my son as he is always with friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and grab this game to see if I could play alongside it. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it because it was the best time I've had with my son since my wife died. Since then this game has brought me and my son together again and now we spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun in everything, it even reminded me to eat the ass of whoever's reading.

Virtually no one in solo queue is willing to play as a team, the game doesn't get new content as often as other games, the map pool hardly ever changes, and it's impossible to get past MG1/MG2 without other people to queue with. 10/10 would recommend!

I am a 69 yrold father, probably one of the oldest people playing CSGO. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing CSGO and in less than a week, he had already played for over 420 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing CSGO. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. CSGO reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

27 hours in, I love the game, yet I despise it.

I'll admit at first it came to me about this game I turned it down. However, after doing some extensive research and not just going off my own personal anti-bias towards shooting games I realized, that this game is just like all others in the genre. A few things that stood out to me when doing my research were the fact that blood, voice chat with others, and the text chat feature can easily be turned off. On top of this, there is no sexualizing of any gender in any way in this game. Now let's talk about the graphics. They are realistic, however, it is impossible to see any gore or specifics of guns or people in Counter-Strike Global Offensive. Overall I believe that if you allow your kids to see pg-13 movies they are more than capable to play this game. Rest assured that your kid will be safe while playing and is all set to have a blast with his friends! Hopefully, this review helped!

The game has different modes, all of which are played to a greater or lesser extent (so far I've been able to find a lobby for each mode).

If you want to reach a higher rank than Master Guardian, you can't do without buddies. The solo queue (matchmaking alone) is an emotional roller coaster ride. Either you get good mates who communicate with you or experience rage quits, certain ethnic groups who have their microphones next to a turbine and don't WANT or can't speak a word of English, or, or, or...

The matchmaking still gives me moments that appear in 15 out of 100 matches, which is why I'm still playing this game. When that moment comes, the mates are friendly, the match is fun, and my skill is at its peak.

A tip from the pro: don't by cases. These are sometimes dropped in matchmaking or are available for little money. BUT the keys - which are needed to open ONE case - cost more than the case itself. But the best is yet to come: the cases have different skins that could be contained in the case. The emphasis here is on COULD. Because not only are higher quality skins less likely to appear, they just may not be in the box at all... So if you want a skin, you better buy it directly from the market.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

11 computer science student study tips
You can use the 11 tips below to help you succeed as a computer science student:

1. Pursue knowledge outside of courses
While a fair amount of the knowledge you learn comes from classroom instruction, you can also pursue topics in your own time. For example, if you discover you enjoy a topic that only came up briefly during a class, you can use your own time to research that topic, learning more about computer science as you do so. You can also research computer science, information technology, aerospace and defense companies to understand what skills they currently need. Part of your research can include searching for internships, part-time and full-time jobs to understand the requirements that businesses have for potential careers.

2. Avoid last-minute studying
This is true for almost any subject, but particularly for computer science. Because a lot of computer science classes have practical exams, last-minute studying rarely works. This can help you avoid the stress of trying to learn new skills just before exams or other tests and allow you to be relaxed during a test because you're not worried about the last-minute subjects you tried to learn. For example, if you have a computer engineering class with an exam to fix a computer, studying the ways to do so at the last minute could create stress for you during the exam.

3. Develop theoretical computer skills
A majority of classes for computer science students are practical, but learning about theories can still be helpful. One way that you can do this is by studying the foremost computer design companies to see the directions that those companies take with their designs. Another way you can learn theoretical knowledge is by watching as new ideas for computers arise and which ideas people test and apply to the industry. Finally, you can read about historical theories in computer science and how they developed into the theories that the industry uses today in order to understand possible futures for computers.

4. Develop practical computer skills
Most of the practical computer skills you develop can be from the courses you take, but some of them you can develop on your own. For example, practicing creating small programs can help you learn a lot about programming that classes may not teach you. You can also practice rebuilding computer hardware and even designing and building your own computer to meet any needs you have. Other practical skills you can develop include learning mathematics that support the direction you want to develop as a computer scientist and learning how computer hardware has changed since the invention of modern computers.

5. Make connections with professors and other students
One challenge computer science students may face is that a lot of their studies are personal and prevent them from interacting with others. One way to overcome this challenge is to reach out to professors during their office hours, even when you don't need help with assignments and tests. Networking with them can help you keep in touch with changes in the field and some of the most recent research they have done. Speaking with your professors can also help you create lasting connections and aid in your future job search as you seek your first job in the industry.

Another way you can overcome the challenge is by communicating with other students in computer science and other fields. Speaking with other computer science students can help you learn better study habits, develop new ideas for projects, tests and assignments and create a sense of community within the industry. Talking to students in other areas like math can help you develop math skills beyond those of your computer science peers while talking to arts and humanities students can help you design creative solutions to challenges you may face in classes and help you develop a holistic network of future professionals.

6. Rest and relax
Resting and relaxing when you need to is a major component of studying for any student. Taking several courses with different topics and constantly working on assignments can contribute to fatigue and lead to higher burnout rates. Making time to relax can help you solve complex problems, design creative solutions and ensure that you are taking care of your basic need such as eating and sleeping. Resting when you're ill can help you recover more quickly, and understanding when you need to miss classes or work to take care of yourself can be a crucial component of your success.

7. Schedule time to study throughout a term
Because practical elements of computer science can take a long time to learn, it is important to create your own study schedule. Schools and universities may offer specific times to study, such as a reading day during final exams, but that's a day you can use to rest and relax before final exams. Creating a weekly day where you study can help you increase your productivity and remember information that is important for your exams. When you create your schedule, try to choose days and times where you can be free of distractions like sporting events and club activities.

8. Develop your math skills
Some parts of computer science require you to know the math behind how they work. Developing your math skills can help you be a more versatile computer science student and allow you to understand the material you use. You can develop your math skills by taking courses that are often encouraged by programs in computer science. You can also develop your maths skills by talking to math students and professors and researching how to do them using the internet. Finally, understand you only need to take math courses that support your focus on computer science and you can avoid others.

9. Learn how to write
Computer science students spend a lot of time learning how to write code and use programming languages, but being able to write in plain language can help you develop skills for a wider variety of careers. Writing in plain language can also help you understand how computer science, people and language are all related. Learning how to write has the potential to aid you in expressing your ideas and supporting theoretical and practical arguments through logical reasoning and rhetoric. Using writing to express yourself outside of academics can also help you rest and relax when you need a break.

Related: How To Free Write (With Tips and Prompts for Effective Professional Writing)

10. Use every available resource
Using every resource available to you can help you be a more versatile student. Many schools and universities offer their students several resources such as writing and tutoring centers, professors and other students. These resources are often knowledgeable in topics you need help with and can help you develop a wider knowledge of computer science. Universities and schools might also offer you a variety of student perks and discounts on programs you can use to develop your computer science skills. Using these can help you maximize your time during school and minimize personal costs you would otherwise have.

Other resources you can use include professionals and companies in the industry and the internet, all of which may provide insights into a variety of topics and areas that you may be unfamiliar with. Using every resource can also help you develop workplace readiness skills you can put on your resume and use for future employment opportunities you earn. Being able to use the internet in a reliable and trustworthy way can also help you find solutions to problems quickly, and develop a list of places you can go to learn about topics you're unfamiliar with.

11. Pursue internships
Pursuing internships while you're a student can be an excellent way to learn new skills and create time to study. Internships often give you real-world experience that classes cannot offer. They also allow you to practice any skills or knowledge you've earned and apply it to challenges

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
